docs.lead_paragraph: A Federal appeals court has ruled that Medicare patients are entitled to immediate hearings and other protections when they are denied care by health maintenance organizations. In ruling on a nationwide class action suit, the court said that many H.M.O.'s had failed to provide adequate explanations for the denial of benefits and had failed to inform patients of their appeal rights.

docs.lead_paragraph: Michael D. Palm, a former English teacher who made a fortune in reinsurance -- the business of sharing the risk of insurance companies -- and then contributed millions to benefit the arts, gay rights and AIDS treatment, died last Friday at his home in Telluride, Colo. He was 47 years old and also had homes in Manhattan and St. Croix in the Virgin Islands. The cause of death was heart failure caused by complications from AIDS, according to his sister, Melissa Jamula of Reading, Pa.

headline.main: Michael Palm, 47, Innovator In Method of Reinsurance

docs.lead_paragraph: The first time Elizabeth Gueits heard that Fidel Castro was dead, she was in school and 6 years old. ''On the radio they said Castro had died,'' said Ms. Gueits, now a 32-year-old insurance agent. ''We started to jump up and down, but I got home and it wasn't true.''

headline.main: Miami Journal; Defying Doom Wishes of the Exiles, Castro Keeps Popping Up

docs.abstract: Article, on 72nd birthday of Fidel Castro, comments on the periodic rumors of his death among expatriates during the 40 years of his rule; latest collective disappointment stemmed from July 19 article in Spanish-language newspaper Nuevo Herald, reprinted by its sister paper, The Miami Herald, and picked up by other news organizations; article quoted woman identified as defecting Cuban surgeon Dr Elizabeth Trujillo Izquierdo as saying that Castro was being treated for potentially fatal brain ailment; her former husband later revealed that woman was really a secretary in a Cuban paper factory who suffered from 'personality' problems; her photo (Miami Journal) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Mark Green and Representative Charles E. Schumer clashed tonight over the tone of the Democratic Senate primary as Mr. Green repeatedly assailed Mr. Schumer's positions on Social Security and health insurance abuses, and Mr. Schumer warned that such intraparty attacks could insure the re-election of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato. The third major Democratic candidate in the race, Geraldine A. Ferraro, sat by silently in their second debate as Mr. Green, almost from the moment his microphone was switched on, attacked Mr. Schumer by seeking to raise concerns about his Democratic credentials in a forum sponsored by a labor federation.

headline.main: Green and Schumer Clash in 2d Debate as Ferraro Looks On

docs.lead_paragraph: Benny Waters, a saxophonist, clarinetist and singer who was the country's oldest touring jazz musician, died on Tuesday at a hospital in Columbia, Md. He was 96 and had recently moved to Columbia from New York City. Mr. Waters, old enough to have taught clarinet to an original member of Duke Ellington's late 1920's band, was an independent operator to the end, appearing as a solo artist with ad hoc bands at clubs and festivals around the world. Performing until late June of this year, he never failed to enjoy himself in public, making jokes in different languages, calling tunes faster than his musicians could remember them, scatting through vocal breaks.

headline.main: Benny Waters, 96, Who Played Swanky Jazz for 7 Decades

docs.abstract: Benny Waters, saxophonist, clarinetist and singer who was country's oldest touring jazz musician, dies at age 96; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Oxford Health Plans Inc., the popular health plan that has been struggling for nearly a year to return to profitability, reported yesterday a loss of $507.6 million in the second quarter, relecting several large charges and continued operating losses. The loss, which was much greater than expected, was seen by health-industry analysts as an attempt by the managed care company to write off much of its problem businesses and past practices.

headline.main: Oxford Health Posts Big Loss For 2d Quarter

docs.abstract: Oxford Health Plans Inc reports loss of $507.6 million in second quarter, reflecting several large charges and continued operating losses; much of loss is result of nearly $300 million in unusual or one-time charges; company's cash flow losses are roughly $85 million this quarter, and it says it expects to have another $100 million in losses over next six months; company says it will drop all Medicare business outside of New York and all of its Medicaid business; it will also drop much of its commercial business outside of New York area, leaving such markets as Illinois and Florida; new chief executive, Dr Norman C Payson, says that company is already raising premiums and cutting costs sharply to achieve its goal of making money by middle of next year; chart; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Forty-one million Americans cannot afford health insurance in this time of global capitalism (front page, Aug. 9). At the same time nine insurance executives earned more than $10 million each last year, according to a recent study.

headline.main: Health Care Solution Is Over the Border

docs.abstract: Jason Reynolds letter, commenting on August 9 article in series on managed care that focused on uninsured, deplores fact that 41 million Americans are unable to afford health insurance in period of global capitalism, while nine major insurance executives earned more than $10 million each in 1997 (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The number of babies who died before their first birthday continued to fall in New York City last year -- though not in all neighborhoods -- in a decline health officials say reflects less drug use, better prenatal care and fewer pregnancies among teen-agers. Statistics released yesterday by the City Health Department show that New York's infant mortality rate is now roughly identical to the national rate, which has historically been far lower than New York's. In 1997, the new numbers show, there were 7.1 infant deaths per 1,000 live births in New York City, compared with 7.8 the year before. Nationally in 1996, the last year for which data are available, the rate was 7.2 deaths.

headline.main: Infant Mortality Falls Again, In Step With Rate Nationwide

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: It is extraordinary that the number of medically uninsured Americans has risen to 41 million while the national economy has never been better (front page, Aug. 9). Children are particularly hard hit.

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite the relentless bad news concerning Oxford Health Plans Inc. -- and another heavy dose of it yesterday -- many of the New York region's large employers are continuing to do business with Oxford, at least for now. The company's unusually comprehensive list of doctors and generous benefits appeal to employees, and that outweighs concern about the insurer's financial instability, hammered stock price and increased rates, they say. Also, there are few great alternatives available currently.
docs.abstract: Many of New York region's large employers are continuing to do business with Oxford Health Plans Inc despite relentless bad news concerning health insurer; several employers and benefits experts say that Oxford, even in its embattled state, is preferable to more outwardly stable providers that offered significantly fewer doctors and benefits and entailed administrative headaches for patients (M)
